Your favor of May 6th
came duly to hand giving much regret at
the ingratitude practiced towards you. But
you have that written which must baffle all
all the efforts of your enemies; the cannot
eqult? long and in their exultation of (what

devotion to their service has been known
I trust that your literary efforts will meet
with more praising? encouragement
than they do here: the few readers there are
are unwilling to pay for knowledge, in
part, with few exceptions, they are not a
people to be depended on. Mr Laruton has
changed his mind on his contemplated visit

for you. I showed him your letter to which
he replied that he could sell as many of your
works (naming the purchasers) as to remit
you $80. but could not under sell them
without your sanction. I requested him to
communicate the same to you by the
Steamer; but fearing he has not done so; I
feel it necessary to make you acquainted with
it. According to his account the books are somewhat
injured; my advice would be to take what you
can get for them, and after that charge your full
price for new ones. Great complaint at the high
price of your publications I friend to literature
told me that he thought you would effect confer
more benefit to on yourself and the public
by sending out your magazines in the way that
Chambers does. Let them be sold by numbers

people will gratify a fancy and pay more in a
small way, than subscribing to an entire work
such is the mean spirit of this place, though
I do fortunately meet in my ? with a
few expressions. My literary friend would
rather feast on a good substantial work
than all the dainties of the universe. In
fact were it not for his librarying
mind (to use your own adage) would long
since have gone to vast so much am I indebt-
ed to my friend Mr Heyman Cohen Del?;
a young gentleman of good parts; clear mind
and would by little practice be a fine lec-
turer; ? for the world he is only the merchant.
I should like to hear some publications of
your honorable successor Mr. Morais. How
strange it will appear to me should I reform,
to see another occupying your place. Louisa
seems to regret much the state of affairs
when she last wrote. Mrs H has not said
anything on the subject but that was owing
to the melancholy state of my feelings. I regret
exceedingly you did not know the date of

my misfortune ? it was on the 8th Thebet
at eleven o clock ? a sad month indeed to me, the loss of a parent at
any time is a painful event in ones life, and when
attended with so much attachment, so much to
render life desirable, tis indeed ? more so.
